facts.text: Kariya and his wife Sava purchased the house in dispute by a registered deed on April 2, 1905.

anchor.surface_text: DWIVEDI, J.-Kariya and his wife Sava purchased the house in dispute by a registered deed on April 2, 1905.

facts.text: Kariya died in 1936 leaving behind Sava and Ram Charan, his son.

anchor.surface_text: Kariya died in 1936 leaving behind him Sava and Ram Charan, his son.

facts.text: Ram Charan mortgaged the house to Prem Raj the appellant on August 16, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On August 16, 1951 Ram Charan mortgaged the house to Prem Raj  the appellant .

facts.text: Prem Raj obtained a preliminary decree for foreclosure on August 16, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Prem Raj obtained a preliminary decree for foreclosure on August 16, 1952

facts.text: Prem Raj obtained the final decree on July 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and also the final decree on July 16, 1955.

facts.text: Sava gifted the entire house to Prakash Chandra, son of Ram Charan, the respondent on March 7, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile.on March 7,1952 Sava gifted the entire house to Prakash Chandra, son of Ram Charan,the respondent.

facts.text: Prakash Chandra instituted a suit against the appellant and Ram Charan on December 7, 1956 for declaration that decrees were not binding on him and perpetual injunction.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly there- after, on December 7, 1956, Prakash Chandra instituted a suit against the appellant and his father Ram Charan for a declaration that the preliminary and final decree for foreclosure in favour of the former were number binding on him and for a perpetual injunction restraining the appellant from taking possession of the house in execution of the aforesaid decree.

facts.text: The suit by Prakash Chandra was dismissed on November 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed on November 25, 1958.

facts.text: Prakash Chandra filed appeal and obtained stay of execution on December 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: He filed an appeal and obtained an order staying exe- cution of the decree on December 31. 1958.

facts.text: Appeal court partly allowed Prakash Chandra's appeal on October 21, 1959, holding him owner of half share.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal companyrt partly allowed his appeal on October 21, 1959. It was held that he was the owner of a half share in the house by virtue of the gift deed from Sava in his favour.

facts.text: Appellant filed second appeal in Madhya Pradesh High Court, Prakash filed cross-objection, both dismissed on January 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a second appeal in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh against the judgment of the appeal companyrt. Prakash Chandra also filed a cross-objection in respect of his claim for the remaining half share in the house. Both the appeal and the cross-objection were dismissed by the High Court on January 1, 1962.

facts.text: Appellant filed fourth execution application on April 25, 1956, dismissed on June 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He made the fourth attempt on April 25, 1956. ... Turning back to the fourth execution application filed by the appellant, it was dismissed on June 23, 1956.

facts.text: Fifth execution application filed by appellant on July 29, 1964 for possession over half of the house.

anchor.surface_text: The fifth execution application was filed by the appellant on July 29, 1964 for possession over half of the house.

facts.text: High Court of Madhya Pradesh upheld objection of limitation and dismissed fifth execution on February 3, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 3rd February, 1967 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Civil Misc. Second Appeal No. 124 of 1966.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal is Civil Appeal No. 1607 of 1967 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No,. 16o7 of 1967. Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 3rd February, 1967

facts.text: Prakash Chandra was owner of half share by virtue of gift from Sava.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that he was the owner of a half share in the house by virtue of the gift deed from Sava in his favour. So the appeal companyrt issued an injunction

facts.text: Appellant made three unsuccessful execution attempts till end of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Fortified by this gift, Prakash Chandra frustrated several attempts of the appellant to get possession of the house in execution of his decree. He made three unsuccessful attempts to execute the decree till the end of 1954.

facts.text: Execution court and appeal court disallowed limitation objection, High Court upheld it.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent objected to this application on the ground of limitation. The objection was disallowed by the execution companyrt as well as by the appeal companyrt. It was, however, upheld by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: In dissent, final decree dated 16th July, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: obtained a preliminary decree for foreclosure on 16th August, 1952 and also the final decree on 16th July, 1953.

facts.text: First execution application filed 27-7-1953.

anchor.surface_text: 27-7-1953The appellant filed the first execution application for obtaining possession of the suit house in execution of the final foreclosure decree in civil suit No. 27A of 1952.

facts.text: Fourth execution dismissed June 23, 1956 for non-payment of process fee.

anchor.surface_text: it was dismissed on June 23, 1956. The execution companyrt made this order Decreeholder in person judgment-debtor absent. Process fee number paid. Dismissed as wholly infructuous.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal and cross-objection on 1st January 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appeal and the cross objection were dismissed by the High Court on 1st January,1962.

facts.text: Fifth execution filed July 28, 1964 in dissent note.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, Prem Raj, filed his fifth execution application on July 28, 1964,

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed fifth execution as time-barred on 2nd March 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on 2nd March 1967 accepted the respondents appeal and set aside the orders of the companyrts below and held that the execution application of the appellant was barred by time

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal holding fifth execution time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the foregoing discussion, we are of opinion that the High Court rightly dismissed the fifth application as time barred. So we dismiss the appeal.
Appeal by Special leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 3rd February, 1967 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Civil Misc. Second Appeal No. 124 of 1966.

issues.text: Whether the High Court decree in Prakash Chandra's suit gives a fresh starting point of limitation under clauses 1, 2 and 4 of Art. 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 1 We are unable to appreciate how the High Court decree in Prakash Chandras suit will give a fresh starting point of limitation to the appellant under cl. 1 of Art. 182. Clause 1 is to be read against the backdrop of the words in the first column

issues.text: Whether the written statement filed by the appellant in Prakash Chandra's suit, his resistance to the first appeal, and his second appeal to the High Court constitute an 'application made in accordance with law to the proper court' for taking 'some step in aid of execution' under cl. 5 of Art. 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 2 In order to get the advantage of cl. 5 of Art. 182, the appellant has to satisfy three conditions The written statement filed by him in Prakash Chandras suit, his resistance to the first appeal of Prakash Chandra and his second appeal in the High Court are an application.

issues.text: Whether the fifth execution application filed on July 29, 1964 was an application to revive the fourth execution proceeding dismissed on June 23, 1956, such that it is not time-barred

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 3 An application may be said to be one seeking to continue or to revive the previous execution application if  1  it is in the eye of law still pending or has been dismissed for no fault of the decreeholder and  2  if the two applications are in substance similar in scope and character.

issues.text: Whether Section 15 of the Limitation Act, 1908 saves limitation for the fifth execution application

anchor.surface_text: The sole argument of the appellant in the High Court was that S. 15 Limitation Act, 1908  hereinafter called the Act  saved limitation. The High Court rejected this argument.

issues.text: Whether the present application for execution, the fifth of its kind, is barred by limitation under Article 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: GOSWAMI, J. The interesting and important question which is raised in this appeal with special leave is whether the present application for execution, the fifth of its kind in this case, is barred by limitation under article 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to exclude the period covered by Prakash Chandra's suit up to the High Court's dismissal on January 1, 1962, treating his actions therein as steps in aid of execution under Art. 182(5)

anchor.surface_text: The question in this appeal is whether the appellant  decree-holder  is entitled to exclude the period covered by the suit filed by Prakash Chandra upto 1st January, 1962 on which date the High Court dismissed the appellants, second appeal as well as the respondents cross-objection arising out of that suit.

holdings.text: The High Court decree in Prakash Chandra's collateral suit does not provide a fresh starting point of limitation under clauses 1, 2 or 4 of Article 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908, as it neither reversed, varied, nor amended the foreclosure decree.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 1 We are unable to appreciate how the High Court decree in Prakash Chandras suit will give a fresh starting point of limitation to the appellant under cl. 1 of Art. 182. Clause 1 is to be read against the backdrop of the words in the first column

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 1 starts from date of decree executed; clauses 2 and 4 require appeal or amendment of the specific decree; collateral proceedings do not qualify; distinguished Mohammad Jabir and Janab Mohammad Ismail where decree itself amended.

holdings.text: The written statement filed by the appellant in Prakash Chandra's suit is not an 'application' within clause 5 of Article 182, as it lacks a request to the court unlike a plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 2 In order to get the advantage of cl. 5 of Art. 182, the appellant has to satisfy three conditions The written statement filed by him in Prakash Chandras suit, his resistance to the first appeal of Prakash Chandra and his second appeal in the High Court are an application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application requires request to court (O VII r1 for plaint vs O VIII for written statement); prayer for dismissal is superfluous; rejected liberal construction beyond plain meaning; distinguished Panna Lal.

holdings.text: The High Court is not the 'proper court' under Explanation II to Article 182 for purposes of clause 5, as it is not the court whose duty it is to execute the decree unless appealing from execution court order.

anchor.surface_text: Proper Court is defined in Explanation II to Art. 182... Ordinarily, the High Court will not be the proper court as so defined, because it is normally not the duty of the High Court to execute a decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper court is executing court per s38 CPC; High Court proper only if appeal from execution proceedings (Annamalai Chettiar); here second appeal from collateral suit.

holdings.text: The fifth execution application is not an application to revive or continue the fourth execution application dismissed on June 23, 1956, as the fourth was finally dismissed due to the decree-holder's fault in failing to pay process fee.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 3 An application may be said to be one seeking to continue or to revive the previous execution application if  1  it is in the eye of law still pending or has been dismissed for no fault of the decreeholder and  2  if the two applications are in substance similar in scope and character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revival requires prior application pending or dismissed without DH fault, and substantive similarity; here dismissed as infructuous for non-payment; distinguished Prem Narain (not final), Hira Lal (deemed pending).

holdings.text: The fifth execution application filed on July 29, 1964 is barred by limitation under Article 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the foregoing discussion, we are of opinion that the High Court rightly dismissed the fifth application as time barred. So we dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: None of the arguments under clauses 1,2,4,5 or revival save limitation; execution courts erred in disallowing limitation objection; High Court correctly upheld bar.

holdings.text: The actions of the decree-holder in the collateral suit of Prakash Chandra, including written statement, resistance to appeal, and second appeal to High Court, constitute steps in aid of execution under clause 5 of Article 182, saving limitation for the fifth execution.

anchor.surface_text: GOSWAMI, J. The interesting and important question which is raised in this appeal with special leave is whether the present application for execution, the fifth of its kind in this case, is barred by limitation under article 182 of the Limitation Act, 1908.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Collateral suit directly impacted execution by declaring decree non-binding on half share and issuing injunction; resistance removed obstacle to execution; liberal construction favors DH; distinguished strict cases.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the foregoing discussion, we are of opinion that the High Court rightly dismissed the fifth application as time barred. So we dismiss the appeal. But in the circumstances of this case parties shall bear their own costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court's dismissal of fifth execution application as time-barred upheld

anchor.surface_text: Proper Court is defined in Explanation II to Art. 182... Ordinarily, the High Court will not be the proper court as so defined, because it is normally not the duty of the High Court to execute a decree.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding argument No. 3 An application may be said to be one seeking to continue or to revive the previous execution application if  1  it is in the eye of law still pending or has been dismissed for no fault of the decreeholder and  2  if the two applications are in substance similar in scope and character.

As a result of the foregoing discussion, we are of opinion that the High Court rightly dismissed the fifth application as time barred. So we dismiss the appeal. But in the circumstances of this case parties shall bear their own costs.
